ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The class began with a live lecture and then we usually had a discussion both as a whole and in breakout rooms.
Virtual seminar with lecture and observations of children
None
NA
We also did virtual observation of a child, in addition to a few in-person observations at schools outdoors.
In-person observation at preschool.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much about early childhood development and curriculum in preschools.
A nice introduction to theory surrounding child development, as well as an introduction to educational approaches and policy associated with this area.
I learned about early child development especially with regard to the role adults and caregivers have on the development f children.
I learned about various aspects of child development broadly.

Learned a lot about the foundations of early childhood education, policy, and developmental theory supplemented by live one-on-one observations with a child! My favorite lessons explained how language develops, along with the socioeconomic indicators of literacy, and how childhood trauma shapes behavior as an adult.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked the journal assignments because they allowed me to reflect on what I learned and apply it to the child I was observing. The group project was fun because we were able to research in depth a topic of our interest related to some aspect of early childhood. The guest lectures were also informative and engaging. However, I wish we had a little more direction on the project.

Strengths: You learn a lot in this course both in lecture and during your observations. It is a very unique experience to watch yourself develop as an observer and being able to apply concepts you learn during lecture to your observations of children.

Weaknesses: There is a lack of clarity in the course. There is very little direction given in assignments and you can still be penalized despite this not being clear.

I really enjoyed this course. My one suggestion would be just to make sure to have some time at the end to go into breakout rooms, or maybe even have this in the middle of the lecture just to break up the material a little bit. I don't think this was the fault of the instructors, 2 hours is just a long time to be focusing on zoom.
The design to do child observations is great. I learned a lot by doing the readings, but the lectures sometimes went a little long. The glad might benefit from a more seminar style.

Strengths: diverse and engaging guest lecturers covered racial inequity in the classrooms, universal preschool, language development, etc. Workload is extremely manageable. Weaknesses: assignment directions not always clear.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The breakout rooms were useful to stir conversation.
As described above, just making sure we get to discussion in breakout rooms to break up the time spent listening to lectures would be great!
The lecture/seminar style worked well but more should be focused on the seminar aspect.

I think that this course could benefit a lot from a student tech assistant. We often wasted a lot of class time due to technical difficulties because a lot of the lectures relied on screen sharing videos.

Successes: breakouts to discuss topics in smaller groups, one-on-one child observations, socially-distanced preschool observations. Improvements: sometimes audio didn't work and took away time from learning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would highly recommend this class! They are amazing professors, the workload isn't too much, and the content is interesting.
Yes, this is a great course to take if you are interested in children.
Yes. Professors Horwitz and Close are great, and the course is totally interesting for people who want to learn more about child development.
Yes. It was a great introduction to child development. I learned a lot and loved the professors.
Yes yes yes! Wonderful way to think introspectively about your own childhood and watch lectures come to life as you observe another child.
